docs.title: Home
docs.text: This is my personal guide to performing student employee tasks. Feel free to fork, clone and send a pull request to this repository for updates

docs.title: FAQ about the Virtual Tour
docs.text: Frequently asked questions, at least personally

docs.title: What tech stack do we use for the Virtual Tour website
docs.text: An executable created using VB to automatically generate static HTML files for each room. The virtual tour 'script' as other call it, is a misnomer. It's a compiled program. It looks ugly. Refactoring the program is futile.

docs.title: What kind of data am I going to be entering?
Collections
docs.text:
• The number of seats in a classroom with and without a computer in front of it.
  • What wireless projector it uses (Mersive or Cisco)

docs.title: Items
docs.text:
• The different types of equipment in a room
  • The TU tag number of computers

docs.title: What type of database does the VT use?
docs.text:
• A windows SQL database
  • The Virtual Tour relies on this database to grab data from. Any changes you make within the ITEMS and COLLECTIONS will be reflected next time the script is ran.

docs.title: What is Access?
docs.text:
• MS Access is a front end that makes your interaction with the database that we use similar to Excel.
    • Essentially, this is the software that you'll have to use to do your usual CRUD

docs.title: What's the worst thing you can do?
docs.text:
• Any changes you make in Access instantly applies to the actual database.
    • You can't 'undo' your way out of it. Be careful when interfacing with Access.

docs.title: About
docs.text:
I created this to make it easy to reference when you're out and about. It's mobile friendly and pretty 🥰

This was made using MkDocs so it uses Python Markdown

docs.title: Author
docs.text: Luis Gascon OTS student employee

docs.title: Copying/Importing to Access
docs.text: I'm not a fan of using Microsoft Access but it gets the job done.

docs.title: Closing MS Access
docs.text: • Avoid saying 'yes' when it prompts you to save it. It will save the current filter, so the next person who opens that table will have your filtered list and that might confuse them.

docs.title: Importing data into MS Access
docs.text:
• Importing from an excel file may be handy but its error messages are uninformative and the process takes way too long
  • I copy the rows in excel that I want to use and just paste it into Access. It should be that simple and it's also easier to see where you mess up

docs.title: Collections
docs.text:
• Identify the room type
    • This step is usually taken care of by whoever assigned you the task. If not, the room is either a conference room, a classroom, or a lab
  • Count the number of seats
    • Count the seats available, whether it's folded, or not
    • Count the number of seats with a computer right in front of it
    • 25Live might give you the number of seats

docs.title: Pictures
docs.text: Make sure to have the displays around the classroom showing the department web page - Sometimes I forget to do it. I just let another student deal with it ;)

docs.title: View from the front of the classroom
View from the back of the classroom
Instructor workstation/podium/lectern
docs.text:
1. Check the sides of the lectern for a drawer. Usually has the document camera.
  2. Pull out the drawer and prop up the document camera.
    • Steps in propping up a document camera up is different for each so I'm not going to bother explaining it. Mess around with it, but if it requires too much force, you're doing it wrong and could break it.
    • Honestly not a big deal, if you don't want to risk it, just make sure the document camera is present in the picture.
  3. Log in the computer
    • If you can't log in, don't stress. Just take a picture of the lock screen
  4. Go to the webpage of the room's department
    • Consult the virtual tour if you don't know the department
    • Just use the Towson homepage if you're still not sure
    • If you're not able to log in, don't sweat it. As long as you have the display working, it's fine. What it should look like

docs.title: Equipment Stack
docs.text:
• Located either inside the podiums or in a separate compartment.
  • Wherever there are vents for cooling.
  • Take a close up picture of the top and bottom halves of the equipment stack.

docs.title: Room access contacts
docs.text: These are the people that you may contact to get access to rooms

docs.title: Door Codes
docs.text:
• All you need to know is the code.
  • Message the appropriate coordinators to get the code
  • Both Hawkins and Psychology use codes for their classrooms

docs.title: Key Lock
docs.text:
• There is a master key that coordinators can use but they have to check it out of General Services
  • The most common type of lock

docs.title: Swipe Cards
docs.text: • A card has to have sufficient permission to be let in

docs.title: Equipment list
docs.text:
• If you're lucky, you'll get an accurate TUBOM attached to the ticket that was assigned to you
    • Take a look at the TUBOM and look for the items listed in there that was added. It should list the quantity or have a column that says 'Customer Refurbished'
    • If a TUBOM isn't provided, you'll have to look around the room and compare it whichever is in the virtual tour
  • Check the ceiling for these components:
    • Ceiling speakers
    • Microphones
  • There are equipment placed behind displays.
    • Mostly small form factor computers, Solstice Pods, or small miscellaneous components.

docs.title: Projectors
docs.text: Take a picture of:

docs.title: The bottom side with the branding
Side with the cables plugged in
Staging Data
docs.text:
• The purpose of the staging data excel sheet is, as the name suggests, is a draft to what components are added or removed from the room.
  • The quality and the quantity of the photos you took during the room visit is very important as it gives you a more accurate count of what's in the room

docs.title: Excel Staging Data Template
Excel formulas
docs.text:
-- Get CATEGORY
-- You might have to re-reference the ITEM_COST file if it returns a #. 
=VLOOKUP(C2, '[ITEM_COST (version 2).xlsx]ITEM_COST'!$A:$B, 2, FALSE)

-- Get MFG
=IF(SUM(ISNUMBER(SEARCH("Middle", C2))) >= 1, TRIM(LEFT(C2, FIND("^",SUBSTITUTE(C2, " ", "^", 2)&"^"))), LEFT(C2,FIND(" ",C2)-1))

-- Get MODEL
=TRIM(RIGHT(C2, LEN(C2)-LEN(E2)))

-- Return image title
-- Handy for naming image title after you edit the pictures
=TRIM((CONCAT("ITEMS_",D2,"_",E2,"_",F2)))

docs.title: Campus map
docs.text: If the map is hard to use... Sorry, not motivated enough to make it work better. Click here for a better view from.

docs.title: What to know
docs.text: • Ask Ben for admin password

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Connect the Solstice Pod using the same RJ-45 cable.
  2. Connect the HDMI cable to the slot labeled "HDMI 1", where it says "4k"

docs.title: Vacuuming Projectors
docs.text: Projector's get hot, so it comes with a fan. Fans also suck in dust. Dust blocks airflow, so there's less ventilation Projector's that have a hard time cooling itself will show a temperature warning and the fans will have to run much louder

docs.title: Carrying the vacuum
docs.text:
• There's a shoulder strap to put around yourself.
  • You will bump into things carrying it. Just make sure you don't bump into anything expensive or anyone.

docs.title: Powering on the vacuum
docs.text:
1. Plug the vacuum power plug into a nearby outlet.
    • Some classrooms have outlets on the ground.
    • Don't knock stuff down because of the power cord getting caught.
  2. The power button is located at the top of the handle.
    • Look for this button

docs.title: Extending the vacuum nozzle
docs.text:
1. Push the slide up.
  2. Extend the nozzle by hand.
    • If it doesn't extend, play with the extension part around.

docs.title: Longer extensions
docs.text:
• Some rooms (mostly Center for the Arts) have projectors really high up.
    • Extensions will be provided when required.

docs.title: What to vacuum
docs.text:
1. Look for any ventilation on the sides, back and front
  2. Carefully point the nozzle at any of the vents
    • Dust should start to get sucked in
    • Make sure not to bump the projector
  3. Repeat until all vents are cleaned

docs.title: Testing the projector
docs.text:
After you vacuumed the projector, it's best to ensure that the warning doesn't show up. Honestly, as long as it looks clean, you're good to go.

  1. Start the system by pressing start on the Crestron panel.
    • If it prompts for a source, click "Projector"
  2. Let the projector run for a couple of minutes
    • If there are no temperature warnings, then there's no problem. Good job.
  3. Click "Finish" on the Crestron panel to turn the system off.

docs.title: Email template for room access
docs.text:
Hello Mr/Ms. My name is , OTS student employee I wanted to inquire about the availability of so I can take photos of the computer equipment of the room to make it easier for our department to troubleshoot in case of an issue.

Always CC the appropriate coordinator in your emails. If unsure, you may CC either James Hardin or Ben Crull

docs.title: Before visiting a room
docs.text:
1. Check 25Live to see if there's a class currently in session Last thing you want to do is walk into a class. Don't be that guy/gal - Some buildings such as Center for the Arts, don't list their schedule on 25Live
  2. Take a picture of the wall plate indicating the room number - Used as a starting point
  3. Take a picture of the lock for the room before coming in or after you leave - Helps with figuring out how to acccess a room
